description: From Middle English loude, loud, lud, from Old English hlūd (“loud, noisy, sounding, sonorous”), from Proto-West Germanic *hlūd, from Proto-Germanic *hlūdaz, *hlūþaz (“heard”), from Proto-Indo-European *ḱlewtos (“heard, famous”), from Proto-Indo-European *ḱlew- (“to hear”). More at listen.

examples: Turn that music down; it's too loud.
What was that? It sounded like a really loud sneeze.

entries.meaning: (of a person, thing, event, etc.) Noisy.
examples: a loud party that went on all night

entries.meaning: (of a person, event, etc.) Not subtle or reserved, brash.
(of clothing, decorations, etc.) Having unpleasantly and tastelessly contrasting colours or patterns; gaudy.
examples: a loud style of dress;  loud colors

entries.meaning: (of marijuana, slang) High-quality; premium; (by extension) having a strong or pungent odour indicating good quality.
(colloquial) A loud sound or part of a sound.
examples: The expander doesn't really make the louds louder and the softs softer in one step  […]

description: From Middle English loude, from Old English hlūde (“loudly”), from Proto-Germanic *hlūda, *hlūdô (“loudly”), related to Etymology 1.
